awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: SusChEM: Root-Targeted Delivery of Encapsulated Agrochemicals using Natural Microbial Carriers
awd_abstract_narration:
CBET - 1605624; 1605816
PI: Shor, Leslie; Prud'homme, Robert

The goal of this collaborative project is to develop a method to deliver chemical compounds such as herbicides, fungicides, and nematicides directly to the root tips of plants where they can be most benefit to the growth and preservation of the plant.  To accomplish targeted delivery, the compounds of interest will be encapsulated in nanoparticles.  Protists, which are single-cell microbes that are abundant in soil, can spontaneously engulf nanoparticles and carry them through soil.  Protists are chemically attracted toward the root tips of growing plants, which means that the encapsulated compounds can be preferentially delivered to the root tips rather than being dispersed throughout all of the soil.  The project will develop nanoencapsulation technology that is compatible with protist uptake and transport.  The benefits of the research will be increased efficiency, reduced costs and reduced impact of chemical use in agriculture, all of which can increase crop production and promote sustainability of the farming enterprise.  Students at various academic levels will participate in the project, and the project will be used as a platform for outreach activities for Connecticut high school teachers participating in the Early College Experience program.

Flash nanoprecipitation and inverse flash nanoprecipitation will be used for efficient, economic and scalable production of biocompatible particles. Fluorescent agrochemical analogs will be developed to assess encapsulation, uptake, and transport. Analogs will be developed across a wide range of hydrophobicity, which will help identify rules for feasibility and commercialization potential.  Cyst-forming, non-pathogenic soil protists will be collected from agricultural soils and screened for efficient uptake of nanoencapsulated agrochemicals and transport through soil-like media. A microfluidic transport assay will be developed that emulates the physical microstructure of soil and the chemical gradients found in the immediate environment of plant roots. The microfluidic assay will enable rapid screening and collection of fundamental uptake and transport parameters needed for predictive modelling. Finally, an agent-based pore-scale transport model will be developed to characterize potential benefits of implementing this technology at the field scale.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
Both living (e.g., plant-growth promoting bacteria) and non-living (e.g., granular agrochemicals) agricultural products are routinely added to soils to promote plant growth and to reduce crop loss or damage due to diseases or pests. However, both bacteria and granular agrochemicals can be difficult to move from the soil surface to the soil roots � in particular when more sustainable �no till� agriculture practices are in use. Making matters worse, most critical roots tend to be the actively-growing tips, where plants take up water and nutrients and secrete carbon to the soil environment. For many plants, and especially certain commercially-important annuals, the tips of roots may be moving away from the surface of the soil at a rate of several millimeters per day, or more. Active root tips can extend tens of centimeters to several meters below the soil surface, depending on the plant.�

The goal of this project was to test a novel, sustainable agriculture biotechnology called protist-facilitated transport for performance in transporting granular agrochemicals through soil. Soil protists are single-celled eukaryotic organisms that are commonly found in soil. Protists that feed on soil bacteria that congregate near the tips of growing roots, and protists move very quickly through soils. We hypothesized that amending agricultural soils with soil protists�plus�certain granular agrochemical products could provide a sustainable and cost-effective means for enhancing performance over amendment with the granular agrochemical products alone.�

Through our work on this project, we have shown that protist-facilitated transport works in variety of systems including lab systems (emulated soil micromodels; custom-designed soil microcosms called micro-rhioslides, and in small pots) and commercial greenhouse systems. We have shown that, despite the effects of predation, soil protists cause there to be soil higher concentrations of viable, beneficial bacteria deeper in the root zone. With the help of an NSF INTERN supplement, we have recently completed a full-scale greenhouse trial collaboratively with a major multinational industrial collaborator. The results show that the addition of soil protists substantially improve the transmission through soil resulting of two different commonly used granular insecticides, resulting in significant added protection of maize leaves against damage by fall armyworm. Fall army worm is responsible for US $6B in crop damage per year.�

To our knowledge, our work is the first showing the addition of soil protists directly leads to improved systemic protection performance by soil-applied, granular insecticides. We recently filed a patent on this technology. Our work has been published (two papers) in a leading microbiology journal, �Applied & Environmental Microbiology� with a third manuscript nearing completion. Through this project, two PhD students, one MS student, and three undergraduate students were trained in inter-disciplinary research. This project has also made possible the development of new experimental tools including emulated soil micromodels and micro-rhizoslides that will facilitate further fundamental research on soil biological processes and accelerate development of additional practical, low-cost technologies for more economical, effective, and sustainable food production.


Last Modified: 02/03/2024
Modified by: Leslie M Shor
